Description:
This explicit teaching activity supports student understanding of how to use context clues within a text to determine the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary.
Context clues refer to the information provided around an unfamiliar word that can assist readers to develop an understanding of the word. They might be in the sentences or paragraphs surrounding an unfamiliar word. Typical context clues may be: a definition or restatement of the word, an example of the word, a synonym for the word, a contrasting word, a cause and effect relationship, information about the topic and subject of the text, or the grammatical function of the word as it is used in the text.
This resource might be used when students have explored literal comprehension and are interpreting more complex texts that include abstract ideas and vocabulary. Alternatively, this resource can be used as a standalone activity targeting specific skills. Teachers can adapt the activity to suit their current unit of learning. There are opportunities for variations to learning and differentiation within this task based on the focus vocabulary selected by the teacher.
Teachers can also use this learning sequence as a model for developing their own lesson sequence based on other quality texts.

Description:
This guide has a list of the 44 phonemes in Standard Australian English and videos showing how to pronounce each phoneme.
Phonemic awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness. Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts.
Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Phonemic awareness is a basic phonological awareness skill and is important as a foundation and precursor skill for learning to decode and encode written words.
It Is necessary to grasp the alphabetic code that underlies the system of written language. That is letters (graphemes) on the page are a code for phonemes in spoken words. Blending phonemes together smoothly to say words supports decoding and fluency in word learning and recognition.
Proficiency in oral blending and segmenting before introducing the layer of phonics lessens the cognitive load making it easier to blend and segment with letters.

Description:
A selection of 8 short assessments that can be used by Years 7 to 8 teachers to assess student understanding of language conventions including grammar, punctuation and spelling, and provide feedback to students about their learning.
These short assessments can be used to provide teachers with feedback about student understanding of the language conventions needed for student reading progress. There are individual assessments that assess either grammar, punctuation or spelling, as well as assessments that assess a combination of these language features. The short assessments are mapped to NSW syllabus outcomes for Stage 4 and Literacy Learning Progression indicators. Teachers can group together or modify these short assessments to suit the learning needs of their students. They are easy to administer and available as Microsoft Forms, Google Forms, and PDF. When students have completed the assessments, teachers can download a class overview in the form of an excel spreadsheet detailing their student responses.
When using Google Forms or Microsoft Forms, the student receives immediate feedback on their answers. Teachers can use this information to inform planning and programming.
This resource can be used for both formative and summative assessment.
The short assessments are grouped by stage with links to K-10 English syllabus outcomes clearly identified. Each assessment question is also linked to a specific learning progression indicator, to assist teachers in selecting the most appropriate assessments and questions to use with students.

Description:
These activities allow students to explore the connections between visual and numerical models for multiplication and division. These representations, visual proof and turning it inside out, are based on the area model and were developed by Boaler, Munson and Williams (2017). Description:
An explanation of advanced phonemic awareness, a sequence of learning to develop the skill and ideas for classroom activities.
Advanced phonemic awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness. Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts.
Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Phonemic manipulation is an advanced phonological awareness skill and is important for phonic decoding and word learning. Skilled readers demonstrate phonemic proficiency.
Being able to delete, substitute and add phonemes in words is an important skill to develop as it helps students test alternatives for reading and spelling. The resource includes details of how to increase or decrease the complexity of the activity by the level of phoneme manipulation and the position of the phoneme manipulated within a word.

Description:
An explanation of basic phonemic awareness, a sequence of learning to develop the skill and ideas for classroom activities.
Basic phonemic awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness. Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts.
Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Phonemic awareness is a basic phonological awareness skill and is important as a foundation and precursor skill for learning to decode and encode written words.
It Is necessary to grasp the alphabetic code that underlies the system of written language. That is letters (graphemes) on the page are a code for phonemes in spoken words. Blending phonemes together smoothly to say words supports decoding and fluency in word learning and recognition.
Proficiency in oral blending and segmenting before introducing the layer of phonics lessens the cognitive load making it easier to blend and segment with letters.
The resource includes details of how to increase or decrease the complexity of the activity by using words increasing in number and complexity of phonemes and also level of skill development ranging from identifying through to blending and segmenting phonemes.

Description:
An explanation of rhyming, onset and rime awareness, a sequence of learning to develop the skill and ideas for classroom activities.
Rhyming, onset and rime awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness. Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts.
Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Rhyming and onset & rime awareness is an early phonological awareness skill used as a scaffold for learning phonemic awareness skills. Having this awareness supports refining the skill of tuning into the sound structure within a spoken word.
Using onset and rime as the units of sound builds on prior learning and further develops the skill of blending and segmenting needed for phonemic awareness.

Teachers can use this activity to target their teaching on developing students' flexible strategies to 10 and working mathematically skills. Description:
A series of learning tasks to explicitly teach students to interpret and analyse a range of literary devices.
These tasks will support students to interpret and analyse a range of literary devices. Students examine how literary devices are used to make meaning across a range of texts.
This resource can be used to develop student skill in recognising, interpreting and analysing a range of literary devices. Students identify and analyse literary devices and figurative language, including irony and satire. While these devices are most often studied in the context of the English KLA, they are used across a wide range of texts, and used heavily in both imaginative and persuasive texts. As such, the activities can be easily used and adapted across all KLAs.
The activities in this resource can be used as a learning sequence or as standalone activities targeting specific skills in how to interpret and analyse a range of literary devices.
Teachers can adapt the activities to current units of learning. There are opportunities for variations to learning and differentiation within most tasks. This includes the use of pair and small group structures, offering opportunities for peer support as well as oral practice and experimentation with target language and ideas.

Description:
Unscrambling famous quotes that are broken into phrases supports students to access the syntax of sentences when reading.
Students reconstruct cut-up famous quotes and practice reading them with expression. This learning task supports students to practice reading with prosody and to expand on the meaning of quotes in an text. This learning task exposes students to words of wisdom and develops their understanding about the structure of sentences and syntax. Students re-construct famous quotes and discuss share their inferences of the quote with their peers.
This resource can be tailored with students by having students work in pairs or small groups to determine where the phrase boundaries should go when reading. Teachers can provide suggested markings to scaffold students.
Name: Developing fluency through unscrambling famous quotes

These decodable texts support the explicit teaching of phoneme-grapheme correspondences. They are part of a package of complementary resources, that also includes PowerPoint lessons and student independent practice sheets.
These books could be used for independent student practise when learning the phoneme and their corresponding graphemes for /j/ as in jump, /v/ as in van and /w/ as in wet and /x/ as in fox.

Description:
This learning tasks supports students to attend to rhyme in order to link questions with the correct rhyming answer. Identifying rhyming words to answer questions is a fun way to support student understanding and use of rhyme. Students match clue cards to a card with the corresponding rhyming response.
This resource allows students able to read moderately complex questions to use their aural knowledge of rhyme to identify correct responses.
This resource can be tailored by having a class developing their own game. In addition students could develop their own rhyming games individually, in pairs or in small groups to be played by classmates.
Name: Developing fluency through rhyming games

The letters provided are examples. Encourage students to write letters from different perspectives and portraying different emotions for other to read. This will support students in developing the skill of reading with accuracy, smoothness and with expression. The letters can be written for business or personal reasons.

This targeted discussion routine seeks the collective engagement of students to figure out what thinking needs to be revised.

It can be used in classrooms where norms have been established such as using errors as catalysts for discussion, where mathematicians work collaboratively through errors to help everyone better understand the mathematics.

Description:
An explanation of word awareness, a sequence of learning to develop the skill and ideas for classroom activities. Word awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness.
Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts. Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Word awareness is an early phonological awareness skill. It is the first step in tuning into the sound structure of spoken language. Word awareness assists in making the connection between the spoken and written word. Using words as the unit of sound supports learning the skill of segmenting.
The resource includes details of how to increase or decrease the complexity of the activity by using more or less complex words and increased sentence length.

Description:
This guide has a suggested sequence for the steps involved in the explicit teaching of a phoneme. A link to a video of an example lesson is included.
Phonemic awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness. Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts.
Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
Phonemic awareness is a basic phonological awareness skill and is important as a foundation and precursor skill for learning to decode and encode written words. It Is necessary to grasp the alphabetic code that underlies the system of written language. That is letters (graphemes) on the page are a code for phonemes in spoken words. Blending phonemes together smoothly to say words supports decoding and fluency in word learning and recognition.
Proficiency in oral blending and segmenting before introducing the layer of phonics lessens the cognitive load making it easier to blend and segment with letters.
The resource includes details of how to scaffold the activity with supporting materials to meet specific learning needs.

Description:
This resource explains context clues and has an example think aloud that models how to use context clues to infer the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary.
Think alouds are an opportunity for students to 'eavesdrop' on the thinking and cognitive processing of the teacher. They are an important part of explicit teaching and can be used to ensure that students understand how skilled readers use a range of metacognitive strategies to comprehend and interact with texts.
This resource is an example of a think aloud using a text from the Eat for health website as part of a Stage 3 PDHPE focus on healthy eating habits. Think alouds can be used at all stages of explicit teaching. It is important that teachers use think alouds during modelled instruction and shared practice as this will provide students with an opportunity to see and hear the cognitive processing a skilled reader uses when comprehending texts. Once students are confident with the process of a think aloud and the focus skill of the learning sequence, think alouds can also be adapted for use in guided and collaborative practice. This will provide the opportunity for students to verbalise their thinking and receive feedback from their peers. Think alouds can be adapted and used with students across all grades and in all subject areas.

Description:
An explanation of syllable awareness, a sequence of learning to develop the skill and ideas for classroom activities. Syllable awareness is one of the five subskills of phonological awareness.
Phonological awareness is a critical skill for all students' literacy development and a predictor of later reading and spelling success. Phonological awareness refers to oral language and is the understanding of the different ways that language can be broken down into smaller parts. Phonological awareness consists of five subskills beginning with word awareness, syllable awareness, onset/rime awareness, moving to the more complex subskills of basic and advanced phonemic awareness.
The skills of segmenting and blending are easier to learn using syllables, a larger unit of sound. Developing fluency and automaticity using syllables makes the process easier when students are ready to blend and segment using phonemes, the smallest unit of sound. Students must have an understanding, of what a 'word' is, before beginning instruction in syllable awareness.
The resource includes details of how to increase or decrease the complexity of the activity by using more or less complex words.

Description:
This guide includes instructions for supporting teachers to select high value words and plan for explicit vocabulary instruction and assessment in support of reading comprehension across all subject areas.
It is not possible to directly teach the meaning of every single word that a student will encounter in reading or use in writing. An important consideration involves knowing how to think about words and their power for communicating ideas. This understanding will support teachers to choose the best words for focused instruction.
The three-tiered model of vocabulary development, described by Beck, McKeown, and Kucan (2013) is a framework to classify words.
This guide explains the three tiers and provides questions to support teachers as they select Tier 2 words for explicit instruction and assessment. The guide also includes an example list of Tier 2 and 3 words for a science unit of study (insert link https://education.nsw.gov.au/content/dam/main-education/teaching-and-learning/curriculum/key-learning-areas/science/media/documents/science-and-technology-s3-earth-and-space-learning-sequence.docx).
Teachers can use the guide when planning units of learning in all subject areas. This resource supports teachers to select the best words for explicit instruction to meet the learning needs of all students.

Description: Numberless graphs are a teaching technique where information in a graph is slowly revealed to students. As they work through a number of noticing and wondering discussions, adjusting their thinking with each new piece of information, they develop a better understanding of the data story in both its whole and its parts. Numberless graphs build on the work of Brian Bushart and 'numberless word problems'. In his blog Teaching to the beat of a different drummer, Brian Bushart states, 'numberless word problems are designed to provide scaffolding that allows students the opportunity to develop a better understanding of the underlying structure of word problems.' He later applied this idea to numberless graphs.

Description:
The Vocabulary sort tool is an assessment resource that gives students an opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge of vocabulary in relation to a specific topic or unit of learning. The tool can be used as a pre and post-assessment, to inform teachers of student vocabulary development before and after explicit teaching instruction.
The Vocabulary sort can be used as a post assessment in addition to the Vocabulary recognition tool. It provides more information about the depth of understanding students have in relation to the words they highlighted when using the Vocabulary recognition tool.
After completing the Vocabulary recognition tool, students sort the words that they recognised or highlighted into different categories. The categories are ones previously identified by the teacher and related to explicit vocabulary instruction that occurred when learning about a topic.
This resource can be used as a follow up to the Vocabulary recognition assessment tool. It can be used to assess student knowledge of the connections between different words that have been the focus of explicit instruction within a topic or unit of learning. Teachers can cater for the learning needs of individual students by selecting what vocabulary will be the focus of explicit instruction and targeted assessment.

Description:
A selection of 24 short assessments that can be used by Years 3-6 teachers to assess and monitor student reading skills and provide specific feedback to students about their learning.
These short assessments can be used to provide teachers with feedback on student progress in reading. The questions relate to a stimulus text covering reading comprehension, reading processes and vocabulary.
The assessments are mapped to NSW syllabus outcomes from Stage 2 to Stage 3 and Literacy Learning Progression indicators. They are also mapped to relevant teaching strategies and links to these are provided. Teachers can group together or modify these short assessments to suit the learning needs of their students. They are easy to administer and available as Microsoft Forms, Google Forms, and PDF. When students have completed the assessments, teachers can download a class overview in the form of an excel spreadsheet detailing their student responses. When using Google Forms or Microsoft Forms, the student receives immediate feedback on their answers. Teachers can use this information to inform planning and programming.
This resource can be used for both formative and summative assessment. The short assessments are grouped by stage with links to K-10 English syllabus outcomes clearly identified. Each assessment question is also linked to a specific learning progression indicator, to assist teachers in selecting the most appropriate assessment and questions to use with students.

Description:
The Vocabulary recognition tool is an assessment resource that gives students an opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge of vocabulary in relation to a specific topic or unit of learning.
The tool can be used as a pre and post-assessment, to inform teachers of student vocabulary development before and after explicit teaching instruction.
The Vocabulary recognition tool supports student self-assessment of word knowledge and can be used as both a pre and post assessment. It assesses student vocabulary knowledge in two main ways; the ability to read and recognise words as well as knowledge of the connections between words and specific learning topics.
Teachers preselect vocabulary to be used in the assessment by identifying words that will be focussed on during a unit of learning (approximately 18) and will also need to include some unrelated words (about 7), which act as both distractors and a deterrent for guessing.
In addition to this assessment tool, the Vocabulary sort assessment tool can be used as a follow up assessment, to gain further information about student vocabulary knowledge, specifically their knowledge of the connections between focus words and the different categories found within learning topics. This resource can be used to assess student vocabulary knowledge both pre and post explicit vocabulary instruction. Teachers can cater for the learning needs of individual students by selecting what vocabulary will be the focus of explicit instruction and targeted assessment.

Description:
The Vocabulary knowledge scale is self-assessment resource that gives students an opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge of vocabulary.
The tool can be used as a pre and post-assessment, to inform teachers of student vocabulary development before and after explicit teaching instruction.
The Vocabulary knowledge scale has levelled question prompts that act as a continuum of knowing and understanding for each focus word. Students use the scale to demonstrate the breadth (number of words) and depth (level of knowing) of their vocabulary knowledge.
The scale supports students to:
- demonstrate word consciousness by recognising if a word is familiar or unfamiliar,
- identify the connections focus words have to other words (synonyms, antonyms and translations),
- define or explain the meaning/s of focus vocabulary,
- use focus words appropriately by writing sentence/s (writing multiple sentences provides an opportunity for students to show how words can sometimes have multiple meanings or that they can be used in different contexts).
This resource can be used to assess student vocabulary knowledge both pre and post explicit vocabulary instruction. Teachers can cater for the learning needs of individual students by selecting what vocabulary will be the focus of explicit instruction and targeted assessment.

Description:
The Word mat vocabulary routine is a visual graphic organiser that can support students in defining and deepening their understanding of unfamiliar vocabulary.
The completed graphic organiser can then be used as a visual reference and resource for students. Explicit vocabulary instruction supports the development of vocabulary breadth (the number of words an individual knows the meaning of) and depth (being able to define words, provide attributes of the word, and supply examples of other semantically related words) of students.
The Word mat vocabulary routine is a modified version of a Frayer Model. It can be used by teachers to support explicit teaching of focus vocabulary as well as to develop effective routines for exploring vocabulary. The Word mat vocabulary routine provides an opportunity for students to develop a deep understandings of words, by supporting the explicit teaching of the meanings of introduced vocabulary, the relationships and connections between words, as well as opportunities to practice using new vocabulary through listening, speaking, reading and writing activities.
This resource can be used to support explicit vocabulary instruction and student exploration of tier 2 words. Once completed, the graphic organiser can be displayed in the classroom for further reference by students. Teachers select vocabulary that will be the focus of explicit instruction based on individual student learning needs.

Description:
This resource is a Frayer model or diagram that can support students in defining and deepening their understanding of unfamiliar vocabulary.
The completed graphic organiser can then be used as a visual reference and resource for students. A Frayer model is one of the many graphic organisers that can be used to develop and deepen student understanding of vocabulary. Traditionally, the Frayer model has the word or concept in the middle of four boxes. The four boxes can be titled in various ways, including: definition, essential characteristics, examples, non-examples, synonyms, antonyms, morphology, and function.
A Frayer model is best used following explicit instruction as an opportunity for students to further explore, develop and deepen their understanding of vocabulary. The titles in each of the boxes on the Frayer model can be adapted according to need and teaching focus.

This resource is designed to be used as part of whole class explicit teaching to develop vocabulary and reading comprehension. Teachers can use the resource as a model for developing explicit vocabulary and comprehension teaching plans based on other quality texts.

Description:
A series of learning activities to explicitly teach author perspective and bias.
These tasks will support students to critically engage with the ideas of author perspective and bias. Students examine evidence in texts to understand how a composer's perspective and bias may be positioning the responder.
This resource can be used to strengthen critical analysis of texts by explicitly teaching students how to recognise author perspective and bias and how this can be used to position the responder. Teachers might use these activities when considering the structural and language features of texts and in the study of current or controversial issues.
The activities in this resource can be used as a learning sequence or as standalone activities targeting specific skills in critically analysing author perspective and bias and how these are established.
Teachers can adapt the activities to current units of learning. There are opportunities for variations to learning and differentiation within most tasks. This includes the use of pair and small group structures, offering opportunities for peer support as well as oral practice and experimentation with target language and ideas.

Description:
The Morphemic word chain vocabulary routine is a visual graphic organiser that can support students in defining and deepening their understanding of unfamiliar vocabulary by looking at words through a morphological lens.
The completed graphic organiser can then be used as a visual reference and resource for students. The Morphemic word chain vocabulary routine can be used by teachers to explicitly teach morphemes to support student vocabulary development. Morphemes are the smallest meaning parts found in words and include prefixes, suffixes and word roots.
The Morphemic word chain supports student reflection, analysis and manipulation of these different meaning-based elements in words to read, comprehend and spell more words, building the breadth and depth of their vocabulary knowledge.
Once completed, the graphic organiser can be displayed in the classroom for further reference by students during reading and writing activities.
This resource can be used to support explicit vocabulary instruction as well as the explicit teaching of spelling. Teachers select vocabulary that will be the focus of explicit instruction based on individual student learning needs.

Description:
This learning task supports students to recognise the role rhythm and rhyme has in fluent reading and how hearing the rhyme is rewarding for the reader and the listener.
Students read and recite words to poems and rhymes whilst having their eyes on the printed word. The intent is for students to read fluently with correct phrasing, intonation, pausing and reading rate. This resource can be used to explicitly develop student's word recognition automaticity and decoding skills when reading printed lyrics to develop student's prosody. Furthermore it develops understanding of the role intonation, pausing and pace has in fluent reading.
This resource can be tailored by selecting poems and rhymes aligned to a particular topic, theme or poet. Students could prepare a poem or rhyme to share with a partner or the class. A poem or rhyme could be prepared as a class assembly item.

Description:
A learning task that supports students to read multisyllabic words smoothly and accurately by breaking them into syllables.
Students read each syllable of a multisyllabic word on a pyramid until they can read the whole pyramid fluently with correct stress and pronunciation.
This resource models the effective use of syllabification to solve more complex words. Words are broken into syllables then reformed as correctly pronounced whole words.
Teachers can tailor this learning resource by creating word pyramids for words targeted in the teaching of vocabulary and topic words across KLAs. Students could envelop and share their own word pyramids.
Name: Developing fluency through syllable pyramids

Description:

This resource explicitly develops student's word recognition automaticity and decoding skills when reading printed lyrics in order to develop student's prosody. Furthermore it provides opportunities to identify and learn a recurring refrain, chorus or verse.
This resource can be used to explicitly develop student's word recognition automaticity and decoding skills when reading printed lyrics to develop student's prosody. Furthermore it provides opportunities to identify and learn a recurring refrain, chorus or verse. Through collaboration students hear fluent reading modelled by their peers.
Teachers can tailor this resource by carefully assigning and distributing reading roles across the class. By selecting a range of poems, rhymes and songs appropriate to particular age groups, themes or cultural backgrounds this resource can be adapted to meet student needs and interests. Description:
A learning task that supports students to use phrasing, expression, intonation and stress to read and sing alternate words to a familiar tune.
Songs present a supportive way to develop fluent and expressive readers. Students sing songs whilst simultaneously following innovated printed lyrics with their eyes in order to develop fluency. This is a type of repeated reading.
Use this resource to explicitly develop student's word recognition automaticity and decoding skills to improve prosody. Songs also present an opportunity to explore new vocabulary.
Teachers can tailor this learning resource by swapping out words in a song. Song choice can be tailored to particular age groups, themes or cultural backgrounds. Innovate by exploring parodies to learn, view and sing with students.
Name: Developing fluency through singing silly songs to familiar tunes

Description:
The use of tongue twisters is fun and repeated reading supports fluent reading. Students practice tongue twisters on their own then perform to small groups or the whole class. This learning task supports students to develop accuracy, smoothness and prosody when reading.
This resource can be used to explicitly teach students to accurately recognise and decode words when reading. Students will develop the ability of a reader to recognise an error and self-correct to maintain meaning. This resource can be tailored with students by having students work in pairs or small groups to determine where the phrase boundaries should go when reading. Teachers can provide suggested markings to scaffold students.
